DataElement.preferredName: Lung Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Clinical Distant Metastasis M Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for the lung carcinoma based on evidence obtained from clinical assessment parameters determined prior to treatment.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to clinical M stage of a lung tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 9/13/17 tt transferred context; changed def - 1st letter upper case; changed Reg Status to Qualified. 12/16/11 - Unretired CTEP 11/20/11 Retired BCRv1.0 content as part of model cleanup task.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Lung Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 7 Clinical M Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A clinical finding about one or more characteristics of lung cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases._A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Lung Cancer cM1a TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Lung Cancer cM1a TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lung cancer with separate tumor nodule(s) in a contralateral lobe; tumor with pleural nodules or malignant pleural (or pericardial) effusion.  Most pleural (and pericardial) effusions with lung cancer are due to tumor.  In a few patients, however, multiple cytopathologic examinations of pleural (or pericardial) fluid) are negative for tumor, and the fluid is nonbloody and is not an exudate.  Where these elements and clinical judgment dictate that the effusion is not related to the tumor, the effusion should be excluded as a staging element and the patient should be classified as M0. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Lung Cancer cM1a TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Lung cancer with separate tumor nodule(s) in a contralateral lobe; tumor with pleural nodules or malignant pleural (or pericardial) effusion.  Most pleural (and pericardial) effusions with lung cancer are due to tumor.  In a few patients, however, multiple cytopathologic examinations of pleural (or pericardial) fluid) are negative for tumor, and the fluid is nonbloody and is not an exudate.  Where these elements and clinical judgment dictate that the effusion is not related to the tumor, the effusion should be excluded as a staging element and the patient should be classified as M0. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)
